title: Lillooet River
text:
The Lillooet River is a major river of the southern <a href="Coast%20Mountains">Coast Mountains</a> of <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>. It begins at Silt Lake, on the southern edge of the <a href="Lillooet%20Icecap">Lillooet Crown Icecap</a> about 80 kilometres northwest of <a href="Pemberton%2C%20British%20Columbia">Pemberton</a> and about 85 kilometres northwest of <a href="Whistler%2C%20British%20Columbia">Whistler</a>. Its upper valley is about 95 kilometres in length, entering Lillooet Lake about 15 km downstream from <a href="Pemberton%2C%20British%20Columbia">Pemberton</a> on the eastern outskirts of the <a href="Mount%20Currie%2C%20British%20Columbia">Mount Currie</a> reserve of the <a href="Lil%27wat">Lil'wat</a> branch of the <a href="St%27at%27imc">St'at'imc</a> people. From <a href="Pemberton%20Meadows">Pemberton Meadows</a>, about 40 km upstream from Pemberton, to Lillooet Lake, the flat bottomlands of the river form the <a href="Pemberton%20Valley">Pemberton Valley</a> farming region.
Below the 30 km (18.6 mi) length of <a href="Lillooet%20Lake">Lillooet Lake</a>, it resumes again just north of the native community and ghost town of <a href="Skookumchuck%20Hot%20Springs%2C%20British%20Columbia">Skookumchuck Hot Springs</a>, which is known in the St'at'imcets language as <a href="Skatin%20First%20Nation">Skatin</a>. The lower stretch of the Lillooet River, from <a href="Lillooet%20Lake">Lillooet Lake</a> to <a href="Harrison%20Lake">Harrison Lake</a>, is approximately 55 km (c. 34 mi) in length. Its main tributaries are <a href="Meager%20Creek">Meager Creek</a>, the <a href="Ryan%20River">Ryan River</a>, the <a href="Green%20River%20%28British%20Columbia%29">Green River</a>, and the <a href="Birkenhead%20River">Birkenhead River</a>. Below <a href="Harrison%20Lake">Harrison Lake</a>, the stream is renamed as the <a href="Harrison%20River">Harrison River</a>, which enters the <a href="Fraser%20River">Fraser</a> near the First Nations community of <a href="Chehalis%2C%20British%20Columbia">Chehalis</a>.
The lower Lillooet River and <a href="Lillooet%20Lake">Lillooet Lake</a> were part of a short-lived main route between the Coast and the Interior in the days of the <a href="Fraser%20Canyon%20Gold%20Rush">Fraser Canyon Gold Rush</a>. See the <a href="Douglas%20Road">Douglas Road</a>.
The "other" Lillooet River.
Until the 1910s, the name Lillooet River also applied to what is now the <a href="Alouette%20River">Alouette River</a> in <a href="Maple%20Ridge%2C%20British%20Columbia">Maple Ridge</a>; the neighbourhood that grew up on its south branch became known as South Lillooet, but to avoid confusion the new postmaster was requested to come up with a name, choosing <a href="Yennadon">Yennadon</a> after his family manor on the <a href="Devon">Devon</a>shire Moors. The river name was changed formally on March 31, 1915 with "Alouette" chosen because of its resemblance to the sound of "Lillooet".
Geology.
The Lillooet River was <a href="dam">dam</a>med with <a href="breccia">breccia</a> from a <a href="Plinian%20eruption">Plinian</a> style eruption of the <a href="Mount%20Meager%20massif">Mount Meager massif</a> 2,400 years ago. The breccia damming the Lillooet River was not very strong, and the water soon eroded the breccia that was damming the river, forming <a href="Keyhole%20Falls">Keyhole Falls</a>. There was a massive <a href="flood">flood</a> when the water first broke through the breccia. The flood was big enough that small <a href="house">house</a> sized blocks of breccia were carried away during the flood.
